reasoning: Central sleep apnea (CSA) is a neurological subtype of sleep apnea where the brain fails to signal breathing muscles. Incidence (~2.5 per 100k) estimated from sleep medicine literature; CSA comprises 5-10% of sleep apnea cases, often secondary to heart failure, stroke, or neurological disorders. Prevalence estimate (~8.5%) from clinical studies of diagnosed CSA patients.
source: Javaheri S et al. (2017). Sleep apnea: types, mechanisms, and clinical cardiovascular consequences. J Am Coll Cardiol. 69(7):841-856
